36.
“Do you think that online learning will eventually replace in-person education at universities? Explain why you
think so.”
Considering the evolving landscape of higher education, I see online learning as a valuable option but not
a complete replacement for traditional classroom settings. I have taken several online courses while
studying in Berlin, where the flexible schedule helped me manage both my studies and part-time work.
However, I missed the immediate feedback and lively discussions that occur during face-to-face classes. I
agree with Ben that the lack of direct interaction can hinder the development of soft skills that are often
built through spontaneous group work. I think that online learning must evolve to create more engaging
and interactive environments that simulate the benefits of in-person education. Enhanced virtual
classrooms with real-time collaboration tools could help close this gap, making the online experience more
effective for students.
37.
“Given these changes, do you believe that automation will ultimately benefit or harm workers? Explain why you
think so?”
In my opinion, automation will end up harming workers ten or twenty years down the road. My personal
belief is that when a company has a choice between compensating an employee or utilizing cheap
technology, the company will almost always choose to use technology. For example, the car manufacturing
industry used to employ tens of thousands of workers, but due to advances in technology, the workforce
has been reduced to a fraction of what it was fifty years ago. While Juan raised a relevant point about
efficiency leading to the creation of new jobs, I believe he is missing a critical idea. To be more specific,
high-skilled jobs like programming and game design are already disappearing due to the advent of AI
technology that can do the same job for almost nothing.
38.
“What do you think? Do you believe the impact of social media on society is predominantly positive or negative?
Explain why you think so.”
Frankly, I lean toward the view that the negative effects of social media outweigh its benefits. I agree with
Ben's concerns about the platforms promoting unrealistic standards that can trigger anxiety and
depression. During my first year studying abroad in Germany, I spent countless hours scrolling through
Instagram, which left me feeling inadequate and drained. I vividly recall one period when the constant

I firmly believe that schools should integrate more music-focused classes into their curriculum. I support

experience, using mobile payments in a modern shopping mall in New Delhi was quick and easy. Not

during busy shopping hours. I’ve also read that countries like Sweden have embraced cashless systems,

help both consumers and businesses manage their finances better. Although some worry about privacy
